name: Micro Decision
price: Complete system: $1790Computer alone with one drive: $1195Video terminal only: $595
description:
George Morrow, the Morrow Designs President, was one of the first engineers to design and market a memory board for the Altair computer. His company was first called "Morrow's Microstuff" and the cards were sold by mail order. Some time later, Morrow Designs began to design hard disks and computers.
 
With this computer, G. Morrow tried to build a single-board Z-80 CP/M machine that looks like an IBM PC but is one-third as expensive as it, and half the price of a comparable Apple system (Apple III).

The basic version included a serial video terminal and a 200 KB 5.25 floppy disk drive. However, the mainframe could be sold alone with one or two floppy disk drives. The Micro Decision also came with 5 MB, 10 MB or 40 MB Winchester hard drive installed. The MicroDecision line didn't have proper monitors or keyboards. The console shown here is actually a VT52-compatible terminal.

Here are the diffent models marketed and their US price in 1983 :

Model MD1 : one SSSD disk drive (200 KB) = $1590
Model MD2 : two SSSD disk drives (400 KB total) + Personal PEARL DBMS = $1950
Model MD3 : two DSDD disk drives (768 KB total) + Personal PEARL DBMS + QUEST Bookkeeper = $2490

The Morrow MD-1 used the Pilot programming language for a Menu-Driven shell to make the computer more user friendly. Some of the later ones manufacturered also used CP/M 3.0.

Like many CP/M computer manufacturers, Morrow Designs offered a complete software package with its system, including:
- CP/M 2.2 operating system
- WordStar word processing from Micropro
- Microsoft BASIC-80 programming language
- NorthStar compatible BAZIC language from Micro Mike's Inc.
- A spelling checker
- An electronic spreadsheet.

______________

Contributors: Gary Clouse, David Griffith

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> DUAL F.D. VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">All of these pictures are dedicated to <b>Michael Dolan</b> the owner of this system.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The good quality keyboard is actually a part of the ADM-20 video terminal.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Auxiliary RS-232 connector<br> <b>(2)</b> Expansion drives connector<br> <b>(3)</b> Serial connection to the computer <br> <b>(4)</b> Printer/Modem serial connector<br> <b>(5)</b> Keyboard connector<br> <b>(6)</b> Serial connection to the video terminal</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>No plastic parts inside the Micro Decision case.<br> Notice the (japanese) switching power supply on the right which doesn't need fan.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>A very compact board compared with other systems of the time.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> Terminal (left) and printer/modem (right) serial ports<br> <b>(2)</b> Nec D765 floppy disc controller chip<br> <b>(3)</b> Expansion drives connector<br> <b>(4)</b> Power connectors<br> <b>(5)</b> 64 KB RAM memory area (8 x 4164 chips)<br> <b>(6-7)</b> Built-in floppy disc connectors<br> <b>(8)</b> Z80A processors, here a Nec D780 version<br> <b>(9)</b> 2716 (2 KB) Monitor ROM chip<br> <b>(10)</b> Serial port controller 8251 chips<br> <b>(11)</b> Serial port baud rate dip-switches  adjustment.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLOPPY DISC DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Micro Decision floppy drives was assembled by Morrow Designs although all the components (motors, I.C.) came from Japan.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE TERMINAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>The video display and keyboard are actually a Lear Siegler ADM-20 serial video terminal.<br><br> Notice the electronic card, a complete computer with microprocessor, ROM, RAM, two serial ports and keyboard DIN plug. </blockquote>
